bibl.title: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, March 1, 1948

div1.p: Lyons has been in contact with the Wyeth company, which has offered to make inserts of the Cornwell painting for the Hall of Fame program. She awaits a note from Lawrence Reed giving permission to reproduce material in Hench's collection.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, March 1, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N. Y.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
1 March 1948
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your kind letter of February
27. At your suggestion, I communicated with Wyeth, Inc., this morn-
ing, at Philadelphia, and learned that Mr. Frank Law is the Vice
President. They have no New York office. In talking with Mr.
Law, who was most cooperative, I learned that all matters relating to
the Cornwell painting are being handled by Mr. Richard Roley, the
Advertising Manager. Mr. Law put me into direct communication with
Mr. Roley and he has generously consented to make colored inserts
for us showing the numbers as they are shown in your own brochure in
the black and white reproduction. When I wrote to you previously, I
realized that the colored plates were available, and as I told you,
they would be expensive for our printer to handle. But I did not in
my wildest dreams look for such generosity as I met at the hands of
Mr. Roley this morning, who has promised, not only to make inserts for
us, but to handle them in any way that is suitable for our program.

I am, indeed, grateful to you for telling me about the
existence of the plates and the fact that Wyeth would even consider
making such a contribution to our program. (The inserts.)

I am awaiting a note from General Reed, to whom I wrote
the same day as I addressed you, asking for his permission to re-
produce any of the material which you have in your possession. I
am sure I shall hear from him within a day or so. As I told you
in my former letter, I am going through your list of memorabilia
very carefully with a view to taking the whole matter up with Dr.
Angell, and when we have decided upon what we wish to use we shall
communicate with you again.

I note your suggestion that you would like to have the
photo of the Congressional Medal used, as well as a photograph of
Walter Reed in civilian clothes, taken aboard ship while he was en
route to Cuba. I shall call particular attention to these when I dis-
cuss the matter with Dr. Angell, and tell him that General Reed like-
wise concurs in these choices.
With renewed appreciation of your great kindness,
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director Dr. Philip S. Hench
Hotel Nacional
Havana, Cuba
